results.title: Wonders of weather. - Volume 3
results.brief_description: Snow: topics covered include how snow forms; wet vs dry snow; the last ice age; snowflakes and their life cycle, the work of Wilson Beckley, famous for photographing 5,500 different snowflakes through a microscope; Inuit people (Arctic circle) who have 40 words for snow (spoken with translation) and build igloos (see “Nanook”(505446) for excellent footage of igloo building); avalanches - including strategic use of them in WW1, the impact they had on Hannibal’s crossing of the Alps, and modern control by explosives; blizzards; glaciers and the effect of ice caps on global climate. “Fog”: topics include what conditions create fog, dew and frost; humidity; famous disasters resulting from fog and efforts of prevention (WW2 airstrips, fog horns, fog “seeding”); San Francisco (in fog 85% of year) and the coastal giant Redwoods dependence on these fog conditions; collection of fog as water supply to lower desert areas in the Andes; English “dew artist” Chris Hunter; differences between hoar-frost, fir-frost and rime-frost; frost damage to crops, methods of prevention and environmental consequences of this; smog, including details of the famous 1952 peas souper of London that killed 4,000 people in 5 days and Mexico City which has the worst smog in the modern world. “Signs in the Sky”: topics include descriptions of weather phenomena seen in sky, what creates them and how to read weather signs - types of cloud and how they were named; rainbows and fogbows; Brocken Spectre; halos; Silvan shine; mirages (prevented John Ross finding north west passage to Greenland); auroras and eclipses.

results.title: Wonders of weather. - Volume 2
results.brief_description: Three 25 minute segments dramatically explore the subject weather in “rain and floods”, “deserts” and “tornadoes”. The first segment clearly explains what influences and creates the water cycle; differences in cloud formation and the life of a cloud; how and why light or heavy rain falls, and looks at the causes and effects of extreme flooding using the Mississippi and Bangladesh as main examples (also why Hawaii is wettest place on earth but does not suffer flooding). Contains many tidbits of interest, including an easy class experiment on how to measure a raindrop. The second segment looks at deserts and the geography and climatic conditions that form them, specifically the Sahara, Kalahari, Gobi, Antartic, Death Valley and Mars. Includes how sand dunes are formed (some are stable for centuries, others are dynamic), and Bedouin and camel adaption to desert extremes. The third segment looks at tornadoes, “the most violent weather phenomena”. Explains how and why they form and develop, why they are so powerful and sudden, and the best defence. Focuses on “tornado alley” (Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas), and the tornado “chasers” - newsmen and scientists who go to extreme lengths to predict the location of the next tornado. Dramatic and interesting visual images throughout.

results.title: Wonders of weather. - Volume 1
results.creator_credit: Yavar Abbas, Richard Burke, Martin Gorst, Heather Couper and Pioneer Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wonders of weather”.
Volume 1 consists of 4 parts: “The weather machine” looks at the origins of weather, starting with the relationship of a planet to a star in creating atmosphere. Clear, instructive diagrams and photography are used to illustrate that weather is not random, but the result of the formation of big entities in the earth’s atmosphere. Looks at the horse latitudes, Hadley cells, temperate zones, polar cells, trade winds, jet streams, fronts and depressions, the water cycle and humidity in the creation of various climates. “Lightning” is a very complete description, supported by exceptional photographs and film of lightning creation and behaviour, long regarded as the “longest unsolved problem of classical physics”. Contains first hand accounts of being hit by lightning and ways to minimize risk. “Hurricanes” (typhoons, cyclones) are more costly and claim more lives than any other type of storm. This episode shows how they develop and what determines their path and force/speed. Remarkable film images include the arrival and departure of the “eye of the storm”, and footage of a hurricane aftermath taken by Thomas Edison in 1900 with a newly invented movie camera. “Things that fall from the sky” explores the bizarre weather phenomena of raining frogs, fishes, spiders or sand, as well as hail, space debris, meteorites and volcanic ash. Surprisingly frequent and usually small, some are huge, such as the meteorite that landed in Siberia in 1991 with a force equal to 12,000,000 tons of TNT. Was dinosaur extinction triggered by an impact so great that the debris blocked the sun, cooling the planet?

results.title: Wonders of weather
results.brief_description: Weather affects everyone everyday. It has won wars, helped topple empires and caused spectacular disasters. Unpredictable, unreliable and downright capricious - this series tries understand the wonder that is weather.

results.title: Wonders of the universe [Volume 4]
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Wonders of the universe”.
Episode one of these three episodes, “Light fantastic” explores the realm of galaxies beyond the Milky Way and explains how modern astronomy has unveiled the wonders of a universe of interdependence where galaxies, clusters and super-clusters collide, entwine and unravel one another. “The Blue Planet” explores how Earth might appear to alien travellers from another world. How the sun drives our weather, why the tilt of the Earth causes the seasons, and what causes the variations in the length of day and night. “Big Bang big mystery” looks at the story of cosmology’s most popular creation theory : the notion that everything started in a cataclysmic eruption.

results.title: Wonders of the universe [Volume 2]
results.creator_credit: Terence Murtagh and York Films of England
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Wonders of the universe”.
The first episode “The Invisible cosmos” explores the spaces in between objects in space - it provides an explanation of the new astronomy, the use of gamma ray, x-ray, ultra-violet and radio technology to explore the heavens. Rather than looking at just one level of the light spectrum - that which can be seen, exploration now makes accessible light from across the entire spectrum. (25 mins) Episode two “Galactic Splendours” takes a photographic tour of the Milky Way using the world’s best astrophotographs. Discover why we can never see the whole picture of our galaxy when we are a part of it, as well as an explanation of the electromagnetic forces which hold the galaxy together. (22 mins) Episode three “Shadows and signs” takes a look at the heavens through the eyes of the ancient and not-so-ancient. From Stonehenge to the ancient Egyptians, from Babylon to the Mayan temples of Central America, explore the skies and discover how the universe affects the lives of ourselves and our ancestors. (25 mins)

results.title: Wonders of the universe [Volume 1]
results.creator_credit: Terence Murtagh and York Films of England
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Wonders of the universe”.
The first episode “Cosmic catastrophes” explores the impact cosmic collisions have had on shaping our earth and the rest of the galaxy, describing the extent of the damage that even a relatively small piece of ‘spacejunk’ can have on life on Earth, and the surprising regularity with which collisions occur. Examines dwarf and giant stars, novas and supernovas, pulsars, black holes, shooting stars and comets. (25 mins) Episode two, “Home star”, looks at the birth, life and death of the nearest star to Earth, the Sun and describes how the universe is shaped by the influence of the Sun’s light and heat. (25 mins) Episode three, “Moonflight”, takes a tour of the most exotic moons in the solar system, including Earth’s only natural satellite, covers an in-depth exploration of the surface and features of the moon. (25 mins) Episode four, “Alone in space?”, is an investigation of the possibility that there are other life forms and forms of life in the universe - what is life and where did it begin? Looks at the use of Radio Astronomy in trying to detect life on other planets. (25 mins)

results.title: Wonders of the universe [ Volume 3]
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Wonders of the universe”.
In the first of these three episodes, “To the edge of time” explores our place in the cosmic scheme as we try to measure the universe. Explains how we accurately measure distance in space, investigates the “Big Bang” theory and ponders the possibility that our continuously expanding universe may one day end in the “Big crunch”. Episode two, “Once in a lifetime” examines Halley’s comet, which makes an appearance in our skies once every 76 years as regular as clockwork. If you’ve ever wondered where it goes for the rest of the time, the answer is here! Episode three, “Solar system superlatives” looks at the biggest, the smallest, the hottest, the coldest, the highest and the deepest - a tour of record-breaking wonders of the solar system.

results.title: Wonders of the universe
results.creator_credit: David Taylor and York Films of England
results.brief_description: Produced for England’s The Discovery Channel, this informative series uses actual pictures and footage from various astronomical observatories, including the Hubble space telescope and computer-generated simulation to explore the main features of our universe which have fascinated humankind for thousands of years. The narration is in easy to understand language and would be eminently suitable for Upper Primary to Tertiary level students.

results.title: Wonders of the deep
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”.
A record of research and achievement in the technique of underwater photography. Brings to the screen new secrets of the sea and shows the methods by which cine film can be taken in the ocean at depths down to 100 feet by a mobile cameraman wearing self-contained diving equipment.
